items.headline: ‘Am I simply the unloved son?’ My mother ghosted me after my father died. Is she stealing his money?
items.summary_en: “No phone calls, no holiday cards, no explanation, no anything.”

items.headline: ‘It’s heartbreaking’: My cousin died and her estranged husband has taken possession of her home. Can we evict him?
items.summary_en: “The house remains in her name. He has since kicked out each of the boys one by one.”

items.headline: Paramount’s hostile bid for Warner Bros. shaken as Trump’s son-in-law drops out
items.summary_en: Paramount Skydance’s financing for its $108 billion bid for Warner Bros. Discovery took a blow on Tuesday as President Donald Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, dropped out of the hostile takeover attempt.
items.next_en: Next: watch scheduled data (CPI/Jobs/Fed) or company guidance.

items.headline: Howard Stern and his 1 million listeners still have value for Sirius with contract extension
items.summary_en: The terms of Stern’s deal were not disclosed, and while he commands a far smaller audience than in his heyday, it is still larger than most.
items.next_en: Next: watch scheduled data (CPI/Jobs/Fed) or company guidance.

items.headline: Pfizer’s stock drops after drug giant lowers its revenue forecast
items.summary_en: The pharmaceutical company updated its sales guidance for 2025, saying it now expects $62 billion in revenue for the year.

items.headline: Tesla’s stock finally clinches a milestone almost a year in the making
items.summary_en: Shares saw their first record close since December 2024, helping support the continued reign of the “Magnificent Seven.”

items.headline: Pot stocks keep blazing after Trump says he’s ‘very strongly’ looking at rescheduling cannabis
items.summary_en: Shares of cannabis stocks continued their rally Tuesday, after President Donald Trump a day earlier said he was “very strongly” weighing an executive order to reschedule the drug.

items.headline: Fed’s Bostic expects no rate cuts in 2026 due to worries GOP tax bill might fuel inflation
items.summary_en: Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said he thought the economy was no longer in danger of a sharp rise in the unemployment rate that might spur a recession.
